document.title: South Dakota Social Studies Standards Adopted April 17, 2023

BB08E63487C6462D8CAF244C5CB1FD6B.description:
The student identifies the features and effects of the modern global economy, including the
role of technology, the International Monetary Fund, the Chinese economy, nonprofits, and
nongovernmental organizations. CE

0694FAEBFDC24AA5BC4BE5D0B016EC1E.description:
The student explains the historical (kinship, generosity, trade, and communal stewardship of
land natural resources) and current economies of the Oceti Sakowin (including select
standards from Oceti Sakowin Essential Understandings 1-2 and 5-7), including major
industries, the role of government, and their relationships to the economies of other states
and nations. CE

7D51F1374E59464B9BF89395C254069B.description:
The student explains the historical and current economies of South Dakota and Native
American tribes, including their major industries, the role of government, and their
relationships to the economies of other states and nations. CE

E85C8592C369404DA3F9C3BB2690797B.description:
The student explains the economic ideas of John Maynard Keynes and contrasts them with
those of Ludwig von Mises, Friedrich Hayek, and Milton Friedman. CE

A00BBB0A349A49289267F7039A31D1F4.description:
The student explains the roles of speculation, corruption, war, and government policy in most
major recessions, depressions, and periods of economic growth. CE

39C6A5085C974CA88457ED80D713AA55.description:
The student explains the ways governments have increasingly redistributed more goods and
services in the course of American history. CE

FE91BD3658C64301A97A3351A3937EFA.description:
The student explains that the purpose of government as outlined in the Declaration of
Independence is to “secure these rights.” C

60AD292B5486494EBCF2290FF94801BD.description:
The student explains how general incorporation laws affected the size of businesses and the
effects on competition and workers. CE

D5BB426AD8714CB79472BADEBB4E908D.description:
The student explains the origins and effects of the Agricultural Revolution, the First Industrial
Revolution, and the Enclosure Movement in England, including Adam Smith’s observations on
the capitalist nature of an industrial society. HCE

11EBDE7E33CB40F491D38CF473463F2C.description:
The student explains the history of economic thought and policy prior to the First Industrial
Revolution, including the economies of the ancient and medieval worlds, mercantilism,
slavery, and classical economics. HCE

80EEC85F2E6B4F559BF0CAD9EACFD010.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the historical relationship between
government policy and the economic decisions of individuals and businesses.

F4C21183B0974767B56C912201AF03DD.description:
The student explains the terms and effects of the Smoot-Hawley Tariff, the North American
Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), the
General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), and the World Trade Organization (WTO).
HCE

F079AA8DEBD54F53851BAF0402DC3843.description:
The student explains how exchange rates affect the purchasing power of people in different
countries. E

32932BA7B06049C090EA642588D9DF05.description:
The student explains the purposes, advantages, and disadvantages of trade barriers such as
quotas and tariffs. CE

EC210E7D1BFE41D4A6F6B01724CA2973.description:
The student explains the benefits of trade in true free trade agreements for individuals,
regions, and countries. CE

810A788FC2FE47D8ABCA59B148600CB5.description: The student distinguishes between imports and exports. E

9BECFB86C20A472DADF312C2F56EE06B.description: The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of trade and commerce.

9662ADB379C348D091185EB630882C30.description:
The student explains how real estate, bullion, stocks, bonds, and mutual funds serve as
investment opportunities. E

D789B9054D3C451292C69915D5F4853F.description:
The student explains the basic savings, investment, and credit services that financial
institutions offer. E

9E159279092E44F1AE263539E90214D6.description:
The student explains the role of banks, including associated advantages, disadvantages, and
risks. E

F21CAEDB82574407A55A20FE5DA13DCB.description:
The student explains how the Federal Reserve can affect the supply and value
(inflation/deflation) of money through buying and selling government bonds, changing bank
reserve ratios, and adjusting the discount interest rate. E

7D2129C15D7F44B193D7533993E8B837.description: The student explains the role of the Federal Reserve within the banking system. E

38273414AB734E738FCB0D8AE4ACE64F.description: The student explains the forms of money in the United States economy. E

F3B5BB16FF6B4BFF954F23BB8CFD428D.description:
The student explains the basic functions of money, including as a medium of exchange, a unit
of account, and a store of value. E

3783C910D44D4BFEA1321D1982284CD7.description: The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of money and financial institutions.

1D0C228C350543ED92A0E6A55E1DA274.description: The student investigates the maxim of “the unintended consequences of good intentions.” CE

DA91E045D938479DA05668F54F7813F3.description:
The student explains how the costs of government policies and programs do not abide by
economic efficiency once social or political goals influence such policies. CE

788B96642176487E975A02F5F77D10F1.description:
The student explains the ways in which government action may harm the economy, including
excessive taxation, increased money supply, excess government spending, excessive regulation,
political corruption, and nationalization. CE

EBDE79F25EBA438F8B7706781D512B9A.description: The student explains how wage and price controls can create shortages and surpluses. CE

4E9F82F0BBFB48A5A80ACEEF252078D2.description:
The student identifies examples of goods and services that federal, state, local, and tribal
governments manage within the United States and South Dakota. CE

DE1E4FB4C08D4A44902CE01E0495AB8B.description:
The student identifies the traits of natural monopolies and the arguments for and against
government involvement in these fields. CE

D826DA5851CB45B78A41F8C02EDF0C4E.description: The student investigates the maxim that there is “no such thing as a free lunch.” CE

49D1D62F95154A8A8576932CB68A5001.description: The student explains the different uses and functions of fiscal and monetary policy. CE

9CC6274719DC48D7A47D4DE3B8465F11.description:
The student explains taxation and the different kinds of taxation, including income tax, sales
tax, corporate and payroll taxes, Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid, and inflation. CE

DA7BA890ED754076A1FCD6B2A41DA617.description:
The student identifies the major sources of revenue and categories of expenses within
government budgets. CE

70618550B7FA4327A53B6944C3D6621A.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the relationship between government
policy and the economic decisions of individuals and businesses.

D05C97FA0BF546A48892AFF24BA7B2A3.description:
The student explains the different causes of inflation and deflation, including who gains and
loses due to each. E

2B0A13311CD540848B2DE82108223E19.description: The student explains unemployment and economic growth, including how each is calculated. E

6D1437B53168420FBDFF933E56442555.description:
The student explains aggregate supply and demand, Gross Domestic Product (GDP), and Gross
National Production (GNP), including how each is calculated. E

737DFD1B8D974DA9BB1CEA11A351A42F.description: The student explains the phases of the business cycle and its causes. E

9D9A00F2CDEE4A468BE1680BE109AB48.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the business cycle and key economic
macroeconomic measurements.

44619457C904425A87C9EE7208E41A5F.description:
The student explains the differences between perfection competition, oligopoly, monopolistic
competition, and monopoly. E

12DF00E995184EC6878EC4150E574B16.description:
The student explains how wages depend on the market value of the produced good or service
and the productivity of the worker in producing that good or service. E

6EF3D6997CA2450EA9F971F1DAADCE5E.description:
The student explains the virtues and skills required of workers to be successful in the
workplace. E

88F336902B40406E8E5CF6B9135AE811.description:
The student explains the roles of economies of scale, mass production, and the division of
labor, especially in an industrial economy. E

7B8826F84B744F948814C333E2F32550.description:
The student explains how businesses can fund and grow their work through earnings and
profit, stock issues, and borrowing, including the advantages and risks of each. E

70D8D50308DB4B68B2F16212EBF7B611.description:
The student explains the difference between sole proprietorship, partnership, and corporation
within business organization. E

95A4D184574F48BBA4D1F0606B60AC39.description:
The student explains how competition among many sellers reduces the price of goods and
services while encouraging producers to increase production. E

D83BAAF859234E4289AF108C3A4B4AB0.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of major market structures within the
United States economy.

480B37237470423EB4ABA7F6C4BC9DF0.description:
The student explains the American founders’ views on private property and its protection, and
the extent to which the average American has been able to own land or a home and securely
hold private property compared to historical and world standards. CE

D745F812CABE431393134CD677BEAB9B.description:
The student explains how defined private property and intellectual property rights and
enforced contracts are necessary in a free market economy. CE

9B84E11F0A334088B499DCDC3E64C6BE.description:
The student explains how the American, and especially the South Dakota, agricultural
economics impact agricultural producers and the agricultural industry as a whole to
understand the trends in domestic and international food systems, commodity prices,
population trends, and trade policies. CE

54D695D5A3884B6AB3FD62FBA0D2280B.description:
The student explains how the American economy has historically been characterized as free
market or capitalist, meaning that the laws allow individuals to possess more goods or
currency than they need to survive; and to invest, produce, distribute, and buy and sell goods
and services by making their own agreements with one another. CE

FAA3D41121ED4842A2B941DE40488320.description:
The student explains the distinction between a manufactory economy and a service economy.
E

0153CBB2994446719E9BE0CC9CC98B36.description: The student explains the principles and practices of other economic systems, such as laissezfaire and mixed economies. CE

BA911DC48CD1462D8740FBC760A0ED27.description:
The student explains the observations of Adam Smith with respect to a capitalist free market
economy and explains the advantages and challenges of such economies in history. CE

37A47AD8CCAB4B1986515FA492C1ACDD.description:
The student explains the ideas of fascism with respect to a fascist economic system and
explains the success or failure of such economies in history. CE

1CBE0F6BEBF749FEB1B715E5D6F428BE.description:
The student explains the thought of Karl Marx with respect to a communist or socialist society
and economic system and explains the success or failure of such economies in history. CE

612A54E96E4942C2BCF522FBF13F5B4A.description:
The student explains how decisions on what to produce, for whom to produce it, and how to
produce it are decided within traditional, market, command, and mixed economies. CE

EFCF974B14C541FC8760639BCB3A746F.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the main kinds of economic systems,
both in history and in the present-day.

A1DA2EA6622D4D37B70300EAC9134E41.description:
The student explains how profit encourages entrepreneurs to innovate and meet consumer
demand even though it is a risk to them. E

E3CC11F773244F6281F60D01FB494A27.description:
The student explains how the profit motive indicates a short-term sacrifice with the goal of
attaining a long-term return. E

C6D91ACD4C9C4CC8AD0D8B2D7A48AFBE.description: The student explains the factors that can change overall supply. E

135487C79B6B468C83470C9F906A505D.description: The student explains the factors that can change overall demand. E

1D46D5608D094E7C98A14CCCDFB7E140.description:
The student explains how consumers ultimately determine what is produced in a free market
economy. CE

E044AD41F01E4DED93BD1E1AAD2260B3.description: The student explains the roles of buyers and sellers in determining equilibrium price. E

081B3206EDB241CEA94CD2A3552C5B74.description: The student explains the basic concepts of supply and demand and their effects on price. E

820E3186DCBF46F1884987196AFD2588.description: The student explains how price is an informative signal for buyers and sellers. E

89E6093B3A7C4E0AB35FC4B6F1F79B7D.description: The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the principles of supply and demand.

0EBDD53CCB4E4AC789E3AD5A428C6A51.description:
The student explains the characteristics of a healthy economy, both at the macroeconomic
and microeconomic levels, including security in the possession of private and intellectual
property, the efficient allocation of limited resources, price stability, full employment, access
to owning land or a home, the ability to save, and economic mobility. E

CC2B5CD93BB743C2BBD4B842ACC0089B.description:
The student explains Adam Smith’s idea that to generate wealth one must work to improve a
resource. E

27E9121E47F74C6B94BD56C0847A9FA2.description:
The student explains how natural resources, labor, capital, and entrepreneurship are
necessary to produce goods and services. E

F23017C17F384ED1895846531600981D.description:
The student explains how people voluntarily make an exchange when all parties believe they
will gain from the trade. E

B6CD4B0EB61F471080E4CF5F711FB125.description: The student distinguishes between utility and scarcity in determining value. E

CBBDC49C97D54B0DAB23141C1317987E.description:
The student explains how consumers and producers navigate the reality of scarcity by making
choices based on opportunity costs. E

59027BB670494B55BDBD39A5BF0F4220.description:
The student explains that economics is the study of how human beings allocate resources
towards what they need and want in order to live and to live well. E

882774EEC3454B64B136DC13F9F812D9.description:
The student explains how resources are limited, that people cannot have all the goods and
services they want, and, therefore, that they must choose some things and forgo others. E

41CC581FF4E445E5AEB69269F2A72E49.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of the fundamental realities involved
in economic decisions.

700E65CEF947482C8E5E864E5889C96E.description:
The student can predict how changes in federal spending and taxation affects budget deficits,
budget surpluses, the national debt, and the consequences for citizens. E

B1850A7C4DDA47AFB0B397184D6C8896.description: The student can employ marginal analysis to understand economic decisions. E

4408D6D1F1784C06AF51F45DA864E51F.description:
The student can use price elasticity of supply and demand to show changes in quantity relative
to changes in price. E

55253C43D50E4828AB4C82FD31AA8944.description:
The student can use a production possibilities curve to explain scarcity, choice, opportunity
cost and tradeoffs, productivity, growth, and unemployment. E

E32CD8E60645471D96A0AB2CA6B3D8D0.description:
The student can demonstrate how supply and demand determine equilibrium price and
quantity in different markets, such as in production, resources, and finance. E

785C5834DCBF45EF83342CB3E5311D8A.description:
Building upon skills learned in previous grades, the student learns the skills to complete the
following tasks, completing each task with relative ease by the end of high school.
